excerpts: Boneless Korean chicken, house chow mein, shrimp fried rice, honey walnut prawns, Mongolian beef, & wonton soup.
mongolian beef.author: Jacqueline R.
mongolian beef.review:
My favorite Chinese restaurant in the City. I'm a native of SF's Mission district, where we lived down the street & this was the spot for family celebrations. I remember as a kid, turning the lazy Susan table top as we anxiously waited for our meal. Now as an adult, this is still by far--the go-to for amazing Chino food. 

Personal favs: Boneless Korean chicken, house chow mein, shrimp fried rice, honey walnut prawns, Mongolian beef, & wonton soup. Yummy! 

Great food & the staff are so warm & friendly. Ricky (staff) is the dude! You won't be disappointed. Try it out. :)

excerpts: We had the special for 3 with pot stickers (4), hot & sour soup (huge bowl - filled 6 smaller cups), fried rice (giant mound), chicken with mixed veggies and Mongolian beef.
mongolian beef.author: Song H.
mongolian beef.review:
We found this place quite by accident when we were in SF and looking for an early lunch. Based on the reviews we decided to give it a go.

In a nutshell, if you are super hungry and need a huge amount of food, this place will not disappoint. I couldn't believe how much food we got for about $8 each. 

We had the special for 3 with pot stickers (4), hot & sour soup (huge bowl - filled 6 smaller cups), fried rice (giant mound), chicken with mixed veggies and Mongolian beef.

The food was good, about average for these dishes. We had so much leftover that we took home enough for another meal. Everything seemed seasoned with soy sauce and was very brown in color. The ingredients seemed to be of good quality. 

If we go again, I'd make sure and getting something that wasn't brown.

excerpts: I wasn't a huge fan of the Mongolian beef, it was very salty and missing somewhat sweet flavor that I actually found in the Szechuan sauce
so I took a scoop of my friends plate and mixed it with my Mongolian beef.
I would definitely recommend this place to friends near by, and I would come back as well.
mongolian beef.author: Miranda H.
mongolian beef.review: This place is good!!! There are lots of Chinese restaurants in the city, we came here as a second option when my bookmarked place was closed for vacation. It doesn't look like much that's for certain. But it was very busy so it was a good sign. It was $28 or so for three of us to eat with plenty of leftovers we actually had to give to a homeless person because we weren't going home. Food was very good in quality and flavor. I could tell what kind of meat I was eating, which is very hard to come by in Chinese cuisine. I was kind of disappointed that on the combo plates for one they don't let you do half rice half chow mein, but my friend and I just gave each other a little bit of each. The Szechuan shrimp was sooooo good, I loved the flavor of the sauce, the batter made the shrimp a little soggy but it was still good shrimp. I wasn't a huge fan of the Mongolian beef, it was very salty and missing somewhat sweet flavor that I actually found in the Szechuan sauce so I took a scoop of my friends plate and mixed it with my Mongolian beef. I would definitely recommend this place to friends near by, and I would come back as well.

excerpts: We ordered hot and sour soup (I didn't realize there would be enough for four or more), dumplings, Korean chicken (amazing chicken wings), Mongolian beef, and beef pan fried noodles.
All of it was amazing and came in huge servings!

And super cheap for the amount of food
Service was sub-par.
mongolian beef.author: Carrie N.
mongolian beef.review:
Very good food. We ordered hot and sour soup (I didn't realize there would be enough for four or more), dumplings, Korean chicken (amazing chicken wings), Mongolian beef, and beef pan fried noodles. 
All of it was amazing and came in huge servings! And super cheap for the amount of food
Service was sub-par.

excerpts: The mongolian beef with rice is very tasty and a huge portion, easily enough for 2 meals.
The restaurant isn't fancy, but it is definitely good.
mongolian beef.author: Julia C.
mongolian beef.review: Great for takeout! Service is usually very fast and the prices are reasonable. The mongolian beef with rice is very tasty and a huge portion, easily enough for 2 meals. The restaurant isn't fancy, but it is definitely good.

excerpts: Sooo delicious and also the Mongolian Beef and OMG THE BEEF WON
TON SOUP!
This is the best Chinese food I've tried in SF AND IVE YET
TO TASTE BETTER CHOW MEIN, Mongolian beef and won ton soup!!
You will not regret it!!!
mongolian beef.author: Carina M.
mongolian beef.review: All I gotta say is try the CHEF'SPECIAL CHOW MEIN!!! OMG it is Sooo delicious and also the Mongolian Beef and OMG THE BEEF WON TON SOUP!! This is the best Chinese food I've tried in SF AND IVE YET TO TASTE BETTER CHOW MEIN, Mongolian beef and won ton soup!! You will not regret it!!!

excerpts: I walked right up the cashier stand, picked out the usual favorites, (Mongolian Beef and Shrimp with Black Bean Sauce) and literally within about 10 minutes time, my food, fortune cookies and change were placed promptly in my hand.
These people don't mess around
and I like that.
The older lady that I'm guessing was the owner or the mom of the owner was kind of testing my knowledge of traditional Chinese food while I waited
mongolian beef.author: Jessica K.
mongolian beef.review:
There is a part of me that shuns fast food but at the same time craves Chinese takeout. It's an interesting contrast indeed. It's not just Chinese food I search for in the middle of the night like a Mr. Chow's or dim sum or Hong Kong BBQ but I'm talking about the run down shack with neon lights that simply read, "TAKEOUT" or "CHOW MEIN." I've never had chow mein till about 2 weeks ago by the way and the experience was like the first time I ever had mac and cheese. 

This particular restaurant was the quintessential example of what I like  in a shack. Red and gold wallpaper, furniture from the 80's, the standard shrine with fruit by the cash register and mispelled specials on the wall galore! I think I've found my new home away from home when I'm in the Mission.

I walked right up the cashier stand, picked out the usual favorites, (Mongolian Beef and Shrimp with Black Bean Sauce) and literally within about 10 minutes time, my food, fortune cookies and change were placed promptly in my hand. These people don't mess around and I like that. The older lady that I'm guessing was the owner or the mom of the owner was kind of testing my knowledge of traditional Chinese food while I waited and I truly found that endearing.

The food was hot, the vegetables crispy and plentiful and the prawns were huge. I was surprised that for the $17 of food I received, it could have honestly served 3 people and then some. I'd definitely come back again for my next Chinese food fix.

excerpts: The chef special Mongolian Beef
i just as good.
mongolian beef.author: True C.
mongolian beef.review:
Another timeless SF hole in the wall. I've been coming here over ten years now, my parents and grandparents over 25 years. When my family and I come for Sunday dinner, the staff know our menu selections without asking. If you speak to some of the waiters in Spanish, they even understand and are able to respond. Pretty cool if you ask me. 
 
The prices and portions are very excellent. I've got out of bed on my days off and driven to The City just for the Korean Chicken. The chef special Mongolian Beef i just as good. I found it rather interesting that much of the menu provided Spanish translation...only in The MIssion lol. 

Parking is HORRENDOUS. I prefer parking at the Mission and Bartlett garage but that's just personal preference. Eating in is great when time permits (the portions seem to be bigger that waylol) but they're pretty fast with take out. 

If you're looking for fast, cheap, delicious Chinese food - this is the place to go. Even if you're not in the area, like I said the Korean Chicken is worth the drive!!!

excerpts: and I've never had anything come close to their won ton soup or their sweet n spicy Korean shrimp  or chicken!!
korean shrimp.author: G G.
korean shrimp.review:
This is The Best Chinese Food in San Francisco!!!!
Been coming here for many years and I've never had anything come close to their won ton soup or their sweet n spicy Korean shrimp  or chicken!!

excerpts: If your a fan of the korean chicken, and can afford it, they also have korean shrimp.
korean shrimp.author: Alex R.
korean shrimp.review: Been going to this Chinese spot in the mission since i can remember with my grandma. It seems kind of unusual to have been here for so long given the area. Im glad they are still operational because its one of the better Chinese spots in san fran. always order the soup when dining in, i prefer beef won ton soup. the Korean chicken is also superb, you can get boneless or bone in, they have different flavors but both are really good. the portions are generous and the quality is good. If your a fan of the korean chicken, and can afford it, they also have korean shrimp.

excerpts: Best plates are the Beef Wonton Soup, Chicken Chow Mein, and the Korean Shrimp ...
seriously, I DONT EAT SEAFOOD ...
BUT I LOVE THEIR KOREAN SHRIMP!!!!!
Love this place, im glad that after all these years theyre still in business!
korean shrimp.author: Jackie R.
korean shrimp.review: I love this place! Been coming here since I was a baby (im 20 now). Miss Mama tho, wish she was there more often. This place never fails, i dont live in the city anymore but whenever theres a chance, my mom and i come here. Best plates are the Beef Wonton Soup, Chicken Chow Mein, and the Korean Shrimp ...seriously, I DONT EAT SEAFOOD ...BUT I LOVE THEIR KOREAN SHRIMP!!!!! Love this place, im glad that after all these years theyre still in business!

excerpts: Korean shrimp and chow mein are great!!
Great prices and daily specials also.
korean shrimp.author: J R.
korean shrimp.review: Best Chinese food in the mission hands down. Been coming here since i was a kid. Korean shrimp and chow mein are great!! Great prices and daily specials also.

excerpts: The Korean chicken & Korean shrimp  is one of the best things there....
korean shrimp.author: Cel Y.
korean shrimp.review:
One of the best Chinese food spots around. Tiny little hole in the wall type places that is really delicious. 

CASH ONLY

The Korean chicken & Korean shrimp  is one of the best things there.... A must try!!

It's really easy to mess up fried rice... Out of all the Chinese restaurants I've been too they seem to have the best fried rice.

excerpts: Besides the soup I also like their Spring Rolls, Korean Shrimp, Pot Stickers, and the Beef and Broccoli.
Oh and they're closed Sundays and are Cash only which sucks sometimes.
korean shrimp.author: Jennifer E.
korean shrimp.review: I always got to this place for the Beef Wonton Soup...I can't get enough. $5.26 for take out. When the waiters see me come in with my backpack they always ask me, "Beef Wonton Soup?" LOL They know me so well. Besides the soup I also like their Spring Rolls, Korean Shrimp, Pot Stickers, and the Beef and Broccoli. Oh and they're closed Sundays and are Cash only which sucks sometimes.

excerpts: the Korean Chicken is great., but you should also try the Korean Shrimp.
It is made exactly like the chicken and it too is great!
Usually I call in my order and it's ready in 10 minutes.
You can't beat that.
korean shrimp.author: Bert Z.
korean shrimp.review: Everyone is right....the Korean Chicken is great., but you should also try the Korean Shrimp.  It is made exactly like the chicken and it too is great! Usually I call in my order and it's ready in 10 minutes.  You can't beat that.

excerpts: The Szechuan shrimp was sooooo good, I loved the flavor of the sauce, the batter made the shrimp a little soggy but it was still good shrimp.
szechuan shrimp.author: Miranda H.
szechuan shrimp.review: This place is good!!! There are lots of Chinese restaurants in the city, we came here as a second option when my bookmarked place was closed for vacation. It doesn't look like much that's for certain. But it was very busy so it was a good sign. It was $28 or so for three of us to eat with plenty of leftovers we actually had to give to a homeless person because we weren't going home. Food was very good in quality and flavor. I could tell what kind of meat I was eating, which is very hard to come by in Chinese cuisine. I was kind of disappointed that on the combo plates for one they don't let you do half rice half chow mein, but my friend and I just gave each other a little bit of each. The Szechuan shrimp was sooooo good, I loved the flavor of the sauce, the batter made the shrimp a little soggy but it was still good shrimp. I wasn't a huge fan of the Mongolian beef, it was very salty and missing somewhat sweet flavor that I actually found in the Szechuan sauce so I took a scoop of my friends plate and mixed it with my Mongolian beef. I would definitely recommend this place to friends near by, and I would come back as well.

excerpts: I walked right up the cashier stand, picked out the usual favorites, (Mongolian Beef and Shrimp with Black Bean Sauce) and literally within about 10 minutes time, my food, fortune cookies and change were placed promptly in my hand.
These people don't mess around
and I like that.
The older lady that I'm guessing was the owner or the mom of the owner was kind of testing my knowledge of traditional Chinese food while I waited
shrimp with black bean sauce.author: Jessica K.
shrimp with black bean sauce.review:
There is a part of me that shuns fast food but at the same time craves Chinese takeout. It's an interesting contrast indeed. It's not just Chinese food I search for in the middle of the night like a Mr. Chow's or dim sum or Hong Kong BBQ but I'm talking about the run down shack with neon lights that simply read, "TAKEOUT" or "CHOW MEIN." I've never had chow mein till about 2 weeks ago by the way and the experience was like the first time I ever had mac and cheese. 

This particular restaurant was the quintessential example of what I like  in a shack. Red and gold wallpaper, furniture from the 80's, the standard shrine with fruit by the cash register and mispelled specials on the wall galore! I think I've found my new home away from home when I'm in the Mission.

I walked right up the cashier stand, picked out the usual favorites, (Mongolian Beef and Shrimp with Black Bean Sauce) and literally within about 10 minutes time, my food, fortune cookies and change were placed promptly in my hand. These people don't mess around and I like that. The older lady that I'm guessing was the owner or the mom of the owner was kind of testing my knowledge of traditional Chinese food while I waited and I truly found that endearing.

The food was hot, the vegetables crispy and plentiful and the prawns were huge. I was surprised that for the $17 of food I received, it could have honestly served 3 people and then some. I'd definitely come back again for my next Chinese food fix.

excerpts: Walnut prawns were crispy and the shrimp texture was great.
walnut prawns.author: Tasha H.
walnut prawns.review:
Cheap, quick and dirty. Come here for giant potions of the greasy crispy tasty Chinese classics that may or may not taste better after a few drinks. The menu is a novel, of course. Has every combo of fried rice/noodles that you could ask for. 

Walnut prawns were crispy and the shrimp texture was great. 

BBQ pork chow mein was the biggest portion imaginable and had okay flavor with a couple strips of pork. Great value!

excerpts: Boneless Korean chicken, house chow mein, shrimp fried rice, honey walnut prawns, Mongolian beef, & wonton soup.
walnut prawns.author: Jacqueline R.
walnut prawns.review:
My favorite Chinese restaurant in the City. I'm a native of SF's Mission district, where we lived down the street & this was the spot for family celebrations. I remember as a kid, turning the lazy Susan table top as we anxiously waited for our meal. Now as an adult, this is still by far--the go-to for amazing Chino food. 

Personal favs: Boneless Korean chicken, house chow mein, shrimp fried rice, honey walnut prawns, Mongolian beef, & wonton soup. Yummy! 

Great food & the staff are so warm & friendly. Ricky (staff) is the dude! You won't be disappointed. Try it out. :)

excerpts: I'd try the other stuff like chow mein & walnut prawns.
Prices are relatively low so that's a plus at least.
walnut prawns.author: Ralph N.
walnut prawns.review:
It's generally a typical Chinese restaurant. They serve the usual chow mein, fried rice, dinner specials for groups, etc. I cane here for the Korean Chicken Wings though.

I got the combination rice plate w/ a soup, fried rice, korean chicken wings, & the potstickers.

Verdict:

- Fried Rice: Ok. I was hungry so I devoured it. Nothing special.

- Potstickers: Not the best I've had. 

- Korean Wings: Crispy but sauce was a little too sweet and had a tartness in the background. I still like San Tung's version. 

-------------------------------------------------

Overall my experience wasn't worth raving about. Glad I tried it but I would rather go to San Tung for my chicken needs. But if I was in the area...I'd try the other stuff like chow mein & walnut prawns. Prices are relatively low so that's a plus at least.

excerpts: Must try the fried rice, honey walnut prawns were also uber bomb
walnut prawns.author: Brelin P.
walnut prawns.review: Found this place while craving some Chinese takeout. Definitely authentic with its own unique style and taste. Good service and food came out within 5 minutes time. If your hungry for some Chin Lee can't go wrong here. Must try the fried rice, honey walnut prawns were also uber bomb

excerpts:
- The Sesame Chicken (my absolute favorite)
- Pork Fried Rice
- Beef Chow Mein and Chow Fun
- Orange Chicken
- Korean Beef (from what I remember when I use to eat beef)
- Pot Stickers
- Walnut Prawns
walnut prawns.author: Chris S.
walnut prawns.review:
I have a soft spot for this place. This has been the restaurant my family has been going to for as long as I can remember eating my first portion of steamed rice... which believe me... was a long time ago. I have been spoiled by other Chinese food and can't really eat anywhere else. I'm pretty sure there's better restaurants out there, but I haven't really found one yet.

First, let me talk about the service. They treat you like a part of the family... especially my family and me. The elderly lady is REALLY nice and hospitable, and the waiters are always polite and smiling. I could probably go on about how much I really love the people there, but I'll spare you... other than share that the elderly lady gave me a box of Chinese candy when she found out I was leaving for Amsterdam for studying abroad... but I'm sure she only did that because I've been going there for so long... but anyways.

The food is great. Well, the food that my mom always orders is great. From experience, I can tell you these dishes are outstanding.
- The Sesame Chicken (my absolute favorite)
- Pork Fried Rice
- Beef Chow Mein and Chow Fun
- Orange Chicken
- Korean Beef (from what I remember when I use to eat beef)
- Pot Stickers
- Walnut Prawns

There's a lot of other dishes that are great that aren't coming to mind at this moment. It's been a while since I've been there, but when I do finally come back home and I'm in the mood for Chinese, this place is mandatory. And it looks like once I do go back, according to the peeps here, I need to try the Korean Chicken :D

excerpts: Ordered: Korean chicken (boneless), string beans with beef, salt & pepper pork chop, mango shrimp, and seafood pan fried noodle.
The food was eh.... definitely had better.
mango shrimp.author: Stephen Y.
mango shrimp.review:
This rarely happens but Yelp you failed me last night. Wanted to venture out of my comfort zone (aka The Sunset) and try something in the Mission. The staggering drunk guy outside Heung Yuen should have been the tell-tale sign to turn around and leave. But despite my first ominous sign, we continued. We were seated next to a table of young foul mouth teens (yes, I've turned into a grumpy old man) and this one girl would not stop swearing... every other word was something harsh and terrible - f-bombs, N-bombs, etc. So that's strike two, if you're keeping count. 

Onto the food. Ordered: Korean chicken (boneless), string beans with beef, salt & pepper pork chop, mango shrimp, and seafood pan fried noodle. The food was eh.... definitely had better. Portions were good and the prices were definitely wallet-friendly. 

Their service had mixed reactions. Overall great but at the end of the meal one of the servers started clearing people's plates even though some of us were clearly still eating. I was getting livid but held my tongue cuz I know once I go off, I go off! Granted I think he was clearing the table so that we can cut the birthday cake we'd brought. But by that time we were just ready to leave this place behind us. 

I can see the appeal to this divey Chinese restaurant. It's low-down-dirty-Tuesday-night-I-don't-feel-like-cooking-I'm-ordering-Chinese-take-out kinda place. It's really a quick stop for the locals. And that's where I'm leaving it at... for the locals!

excerpts: I swear I can tell the noodles in our bland, greasy tomato beef chow mein, were fried in lard.
Yes, I can tell the diff.
Cuz I'm the noodle (and sushi) king, no lie.
Noodle G"?
Nah that sounds kinda stupid.
Anyway, truthfully, after eating here, my toes and fingers were numb (bad circulation) till the next day.
So, if you're a twenty something, you ain't gonna be listenin to me about what you put in your body past your tastebuds anyway.

But if you're around 40, then you'll know after the first few bites, that you ain't got no biz eatin this stuff, and putting your body through this, unless your BFF works in the ER and your second BFF is a paramedic to get you there.
(Just think of your spouse and kids, and you'll be outta here and on the 48 back to The Sunset in a minute.)
tomato beef chow mein.author: George F.
tomato beef chow mein.review: Even though I spent some of my best childhood years growing up in the "Mission District" (us prehistoric originals never call it in Google hipsterese "I'm so cool I live in "The Mission,") I usually avoid eating in the neighborhood I grew up in, thinking of it as kind of the SF version of "The Occupied West Bank" and my original Latino Homiez and their families as the Frisco version of The Palestinians, driven out of their homes by new settlers who claim that the new Google gods gave them the right. But I was invited to have lunch there by an old neighborhood friend who said that he has been eating here at Heung Yuen for 30 years, since he was 2. I should have known better, especially since he's 32 and can hardly walk already, and his right leg is permanently asleep due to poor circulation. But I wanted to see him, so here I was, feeling like I was walking through "occupied Hebron" in "hipster territory" heehee, amid the new "invisible checkpoints," the $100 bistro tabs, designed to keep the original locals out, and among all the $20 coffee "boutiques" and Birkenstock wearing "loungers," acting like they owned these streets, the hallowed grounds where "Los Siete De La Raza roamed" (Google it for more info haha, Google again, such irony,) and the 24th St Boyz held sway, finding my way to Heung Yuen. I sighed when I saw that this place truly hasn't changed from the outside, (and inside) since my childhood, but now, oddly out of place amid the slick themed bistros and bars around it. So anyway, I seldom talk about "health" in these reviews because the assumption is that if my butt is in that chair, it ain't gonna kill me (or you.) But this time I have to  seriously consider my own (and your) mortality when I talk about Heung Yuen, and especially that often reviewed  "sent from heaven" conqueror of the yelp universe, superhero "Korean" chicken. Which btw, truthfully is not really "Korean" or associated with real "Korean chicken"'in any way shape or form. Those of you that are Korean (from The Big K,) or second generation, and know about this, or If you're under 30 and don't know, ask your parents about "Pelicana Chicken," in Korea, the original, who pioneered and commercialized this type, (deep fried glazed,) the template, the "real" no lie, and always the best, and you will know that Heung Yuen's (although yes, crunchy on the outside and yes tender inside,) version's flavors are off, no balance between hot and spicy. An amateur overly sweet snd gratuitously unhealthy, wanna be knock off. A Cantonese cooks mistaken impression of what Korean chicken "must be like." So seriously my hipster settler heroes. Since you put so much money and effort into driving my Latino homiez and their families out of their Mission District homes, and changed its character with your google salaries, then maybe you should start saving some artery space from now on so you can enjoy it, by avoiding this place. So I'm not gonna run with the pack on this one. Two stars max for cheap prices. POSTSCRIPT: After lunch there, I sat on "the throne" all afternoon and into the evening and night, and no I ain't the dang Last Emperor. Haha, very funny.  I swear I can tell the noodles in our bland, greasy tomato beef chow mein, were fried in lard. Yes, I can tell the diff. Cuz I'm the noodle (and sushi) king, no lie. "Noodle G"?" Nah that sounds kinda stupid. Anyway, truthfully, after eating here, my toes and fingers were numb (bad circulation) till the next day. So, if you're a twenty something, you ain't gonna be listenin to me about what you put in your body past your tastebuds anyway. But if you're around 40, then you'll know after the first few bites, that you ain't got no biz eatin this stuff, and putting your body through this, unless your BFF works in the ER and your second BFF is a paramedic to get you there. (Just think of your spouse and kids, and you'll be outta here and on the 48 back to The Sunset in a minute.)

excerpts: but I absolutely love the beef fried rice and beef chow mein.
The fried rice was usually my regular and one of the employees know how I like it spicy.
Now thats a plus - a man who remembers what you tell them;
beef fried rice.author: Sadia B.
beef fried rice.review:
The struggle of finding a good go-to Chinese restaurant that actually has decent, if not delicious, and cheap food is near impossible.. Until I found this place.

I used to attend City college near Bartlett street and there was this little Chinese hole-in-the wall that I would always pass by when getting breakfast at the Crepe House. To this day, I never understood why I never checked it out. I have honestly passed this restaurant for years, picking up my little brother and such. One day I finally have it a shot and I wish I remembered the date because oh my goodness.. Lets just say every time I pass by it now, I always want to go in! 

I'm very picky and I like to go to certain places to eat certain things. I haven't eaten much on their menu but I absolutely love the beef fried rice and beef chow mein. The fried rice was usually my regular and one of the employees know how I like it spicy. Now thats a plus - a man who remembers what you tell them; Ha! 

This is now one of my favorite places. And may I add that it's close to home. :)

excerpts: We ordered the garlic green beans, sesame chicken, beef broccoli, chicken won ton soup, and bbq pork fried rice.
The won ton soup, sesame chicken, and garlic green beans were amazing.
Would definitely recommend.
The service was very fast and super friendly.
The ambience inside could use a little TLC but that would be my only suggestion and we did take out so i could care less.
bbq pork fried rice.author: Emma V.
bbq pork fried rice.review: Ordered take out from here for the first time tonight. We ordered the garlic green beans, sesame chicken, beef broccoli, chicken won ton soup, and bbq pork fried rice. The won ton soup, sesame chicken, and garlic green beans were amazing. Would definitely recommend. The service was very fast and super friendly. The ambience inside could use a little TLC but that would be my only suggestion and we did take out so i could care less. :)

excerpts: Per the rave reviews, we ordered the Korean fried chicken boneless and got a side of white rice and their Chef Special chow mein.
Yes the chicken was yummy!
I felt like it had more breading than meat, but that's what makes it so good, right?
The chicken was fried just right, making it crispy and juicy.
And that sauce.
Omg that sauce is killer!
I'm wondering if they'll share that recipe with me
so I can whip it up at home and slather all types of meat into it.
I think it's just honey and some sort of spicy sauce and crushed red peppers.
The chow mein was fine.
white rice.author: Joy L.
white rice.review:
Pretty decent Chinese food. Per the rave reviews, we ordered the Korean fried chicken boneless and got a side of white rice and their Chef Special chow mein. Yes the chicken was yummy! I felt like it had more breading than meat, but that's what makes it so good, right? The chicken was fried just right, making it crispy and juicy. And that sauce. Omg that sauce is killer! I'm wondering if they'll share that recipe with me so I can whip it up at home and slather all types of meat into it. I think it's just honey and some sort of spicy sauce and crushed red peppers. The chow mein was fine. It was pretty oily and they were stingey when it came to meat and vegetables, but we still enjoyed it.  

The staff is friendly and attentive. It's certainly not a place where you'd wanna take a first date to (it was obviously a Mexican restaurant in its past life), so you can call in your order for pick up if you prefer that. Also, they're closed on Sundays.

excerpts: Pick the white rice over the fried.
Great to bring home for parties, just got Korean chix , shrimp chow mein, and beef broccoil 4 my b-day
and it was a hit!
The service is great, I know them since I was little, the old lady is the best!
It's a family hot spot!
white rice.author: Ladyreyes R.
white rice.review: Great food! Korean Chix is a must and the shrimp chow mein! Beef broccoli and won ton soup are great too! Pick the white rice over the fried. Great to bring home for parties, just got Korean chix , shrimp chow mein, and beef broccoil 4 my b-day and it was a hit! The service is great, I know them since I was little, the old lady is the best! It's a family hot spot!
